clinical_study.official_title: Home- and Lab-Based Passive and Active Movement Rehabilitation of Ankle Impairments in Children With Cerebral Palsy - A Randomized Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to investigate the effectiveness of home-based and lab-based stretching and active movement rehabilitation in reducing joint impairments in cerebral palsy using a portable rehabilitation robot. Children with spastic cerebral palsy and ankle impairments are divided randomly into two groups, participating in robot-guided passive and active movement training in a research lab setting (lab group) or in home setting (home group).

detailed_description.textblock:
The participants are randomly assigned to the lab group or home group.
For the lab-based training (lab group), the participation will involve 18 training sessions over six weeks with 3 sessions/week. In addition, there are 3 visits for outcome evaluations carried out before and after the six-week training, and at six weeks after the multi-week training as follow-up.
For the home-based training (home group), the training will last for six weeks and will take place at least three times a week at home, after the participants have been instructed and trained on how to use the portable rehabilitation robot properly. Participants will come to the research lab for outcome evaluations before, after the six week training, and at follow up.
For the home group, the participants will be initially trained by the research team at the lab setting on how to use the rehabilitation robot. The training will be done over the first one or two sessions. The research team will go through with the participants and family members on how to operate the rehabilitation robot at home. The participants and their family members practice using the rehabilitation robot at the lab setting until they feel comfortable using the robot independently. Before taking the device home, the participants are asked to go through each step of the training without assistance from the research staff. After the training, the participants and family member will take the portable rehabilitation robot home using their own vehicles and conduct the training at home. Audiovisual interaction and instruction can be done through Internet if the participants need help in conducting the training. Training data and results saved in the rehabilitation robot, which can be uploaded to the server managed by the research team. Training parameters can be adjusted based on the progress.
For both groups, in each of the 18 training sessions, the participant is seated with the foot attached to a footplate and leg fixed by a leg-support. The ankle joint will be rotated slowly to the joint extreme upward and downward to stretch the joint. The participant is also asked to move the joint voluntarily to play videogames on a computer. Each treatment session lasts approximately one hour.
Outcome Evaluations
Evaluations are done before, after the training treatment sessions, and at the follow-up. During the evaluation sessions, the ankle will be moved by the robot to evaluate the passive properties including passive range of motion and joint stiffness. The participants will also move the ankle voluntarily and their active control ability including active range of motion and muscle strength will be evaluated. Clinical examination is done to evaluate clinical scales including modified Ashworth scale, selective control Assessment of lower extremity (SCALE), balance, and walking ability (distance covered in 6 minutes).

arm_group.description: Lab-based intervention includes 18 lab-based training and 3 evaluations at lab using the Intelligent Stretcher. The study involves 6-week intervention and three evaluations in the research lab (pre-, post and 6-week follow-up after the end of the intervention).

Home-based intervention includes 18 home-based training sessions and 3 evaluations in lab using Intelligent Stretcher. The study involves 6-week intervention at home and three evaluations in the research lab (pre-, post and 6-week follow-up after the end of the intervention).

intervention.description: The impaired ankle of the participants are trained 3 sessions a week for 6 weeks in lab/at home. The participants use the portable robot in passive mode to increase range of motion (ROM), then subjects use their gained ROM immediately in the active movement to train their impaired ankle in controlling game play and improve motor control.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Have a diagnosis of a neurological disorder specifically: cerebral palsy with diplegia, hemiplegia or quadriplegia stroke with hemiplegia, TBI with hemiplegia or quadriplegia, or SCI with quadriplegia or paraplegia.
- Spasticity in joint with a MAS >0
- At intended joint of treatment: has limited joint mobility
Exclusion Criteria:
- Subjects who have other unrelated neurological impairments or musculoskeletal injuries
- Patients who have had orthopedic surgery within 6 months prior to participation in study.
- Patients who have severe pain in the paralyzed limb
